title: Should all tablets have one?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2023
text: The stylus seems to be a feature fewer and fewer tablets have these days. I do like the improved accuracy you get vs your finger, especially when you move from mobile optimized sites to desktop ones. And yes desktop view looks better on a big screen, so I say the answer is yes, all tablets should have a proper stylus.The Apple Pencil Mk2 does pair and charge easily via magnetic snapping. Note the iPad does not have a housing for the pencil, I recommend getting a third party case/cover that does. Even though it is magnetic doesn‚Äôt mean it can‚Äôt come loose and be lost and this accessory is not cheap. The flat, touch sensitive interface feels awkward and I don‚Äôt think Apple has fully realized its usage. The more tactile ‚Äúvolume dial‚Äù of a Wacom (or similar) stylus is better for implementing controls and switches when painting/drawing‚Ä¶but such discussion is of scope considering we are talking about an iPad accessory, and this isn‚Äôt a review of the iPad drawing experience.

title: READ BEFORE BUYING OFF AMAZON WAREHOUSE
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2023
text: TL;DR. Have serious caution when buying off of Amazon Warehouse.I originally purchased this 2nd gen Apple Pencil for a discounted rate off of the Amazon warehouse. It was supposed to be a 2 day delivery, ended up being 6. Fine, no big deal, I saved money. The package shows up in original packaging AND THERE WAS NO PENCIL. None. I paid $80 for a box. I could not contact Amazon about the order or leave a review, so I requested a refund.I ended up buying the pencil for full price. And it works great! Definitely recommend it.

title: Works like a charm
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2023
text: Really nice pencil/stylus from Apple. Genuine Apple pencil 2. I got it for a backup to my other Apple pencil 2 for when the battery gets low after using it for hours. It works perfectly. Now I can switch out pencils and not have to wait for one to recharge before resuming drawing. NOTE: A big issue is that you can't charge one pencil on the iPad while using the other one. It's only one pencil per iPad at a time. So you have to charge the other pencil on a different iPad. This is something Apple needs to change.

title: Most efficient for apple
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2023
text: I bought it for my iPad about two months ago and it is the best combination, being in the apple eco-system it is highly compatible with it, however, it doesn't work with the other devices if you were curious. The magnetic hold is strong and doesn't fall off easily, and the touch has never been an issue, I have not explicitly tried but I have never run out of battery, and being a student I use the pencil for 3 hours straight twice or even thrice a day without any charging issues. Finally, the only real issue is that you'll need to download and might even have to pay for the right apps to get the best out of it.

title: Great to use but there are issues
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2023
text: The pencil when it connects to the iPad works great. But there are bugs maybe to the iPad os or to the pencil itself that makes it disconnect to the iPad and no matter what it doesn‚Äôt connect back. Happened to me and I hit forget device, reconnected, and it worked. Happened again after a month, so I hit forget this device and it was gone. Tried everything but nothing worked. Thankfully Amazon still took it back after the 30 days were up. Mind you the pencil was but 4 months in use and hadn‚Äôt been damaged in the slightest. I also heard if taken to the Apple Store they will usually take the broken one back and get you another one (probably done within the one year manufacture warranty).

title: Works great but a little too tap sensitive which I fixed with a little fabric.

text: Overall, it works great! But it keeps thinking I'm tapping it so it changes tips when i don't want it to change. So, I made a thin sleeve out of fabric, 1-2 thicknesses. I hold it together with 3 thin strips of tape. (cut the fabric to size, wrap around the pencil and hold tight, and tape.) Now I can still tap to change tips but it doesn't change on its own very much any more. I take it off to charge the pencil.With this, I'd give it 5 stars.

title: This thing changed the game for my iPad art and design
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2022
text: I previously had an iPad Air 2 and used an Adonit pixel since the air is not compatible with the Apple Pencil. It didn‚Äôt work that well but it did what I needed with some bugs and jitters. I finally upgraded to the 2021 iPad Pro 11 inch and I got the Apple Pencil 2 when it went on sale. I have been SO impressed with this thing. I love the way it writes and draws it feels like I‚Äôm writing on paper and the smoothness of the line is stellar. It completely changed the game for me when I work on my art and design. I use procreate and they have many updated features that include options for the Apple Pencil so the integration with all of the apps I already use is phenomenal. I think the sale price I paid for 89.99 is more than reasonable but I couldn‚Äôt see myself paying full price for this even with how impressive it is. But at the sale price I am more than satisfied.The only thing that I don‚Äôt like is the magnetic feature that is supposed to keep it on the iPad and is how it charges. I have put the iPad in my backpack with the pencil attached and then when I pull it out the pencil wasn‚Äôt attached anymore. I of course had a small panic but then found it in the bottom of my bag so no but deal. I just wish it had some other mechanism that kept the pencil more secured, but I will say the fact that I don‚Äôt have to plug it in to anything to charge it is definitely convenient.

title: A must-have if you use an iPad for notes
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2022
text: I decided to buy myself an iPad Air 4 for my birthday in 2019 because I was returning to school. Getting the Apple Pencil with it was a game changer.I'm in my 30s and I am a person who loves physical books and writing on paper. I was hesitant to buy an iPad for notes, but after watching classmates use them and asking them questions, it seemed like it would be really beneficial.I bought a paperlike screen protector, and I love using my apple pencil for writing! It has gotten to the point where I am double tapping on actual pencils because I have just become completely assimilated to writing on an iPad. It is very intuitive and has a variety of uses.I never had the 1st gen apple pencil, but I love the magnetic charging and double tap so I do think the 2nd generation is worth the extra price.I bought a 6-pack of tips in 2019 and I still have plenty left even though I write on my iPad regularly.My ONLY gripe is that the pencils are so specific to different models. My son has the 2020 iPad and my pencil won't work on his iPad because it isn't a Pro or Air model. It would be nice if Apple was able to make an update that allowed the different pencils to be compatible on all models.

text: I got my Apple Pencil 2nd Generation while on sale! Awesome deal! It made my iPad Pro12.9 inch come alive. Pairing was simple, just a matter of it magnetically attaching to the side of my iPad. It also charges fast while attached. Under Settings on the iPad there is a Pencil section. I suggest going there to try out some of the features of the Apple Pencil. It writes very smoothly on the screen. I do recommend placing a screen protector on your iPad (as well as your iPhone) for general purpose protection. It felt good in my hand, sort of like one of those pencils we used in First Grade. I have large hands, so someone with small hands might need an optional Pencil Grip. I found the accuracy of the Apple Pencil to be spot on. I went into the Notes app and practiced a lot to get used to the features. If you are teetering on the edge trying to decide whether or not to get the Apple Pencil, go for it, especially while it‚Äôs on sale. You will be amazed at the things you can do with it.

title: The Fountain pencil of IPads
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2021
text: I wanted to give this a 4 star only due to the price but even for the price it really is worth it. For me, I‚Äôm big on writing with fountain pens and I was expecting this to be a bit bulky but when I got it in person and using it the Apple Pencil is quite slim and has a long thin barrel design. It is very very comfortable to use and is quite light. I enjoyed that it paired with my iPad Pro (12.9 M1 model) instantly and brought up the scribble setting to give you a nice straight forward tutorial. That was awesome and after a couple of minutes it really becomes quite second nature and an extension of your pointer finger so using it to navigate around IPad is pretty nice. I was using it in VLC to adjust brightness, volume, etc and then I been using this every day for writing practice and daily planning and I am using a glass screen protector and it really just glides across the glass just like when I would use my fountain pens on paper and I love that. The pressure sensitivity is definitely impressive. I use both normal scripture and caligraphic scripture and it handles those strokes with ease and is quite enjoyable. The battery is also very very nice. I can write for over 45 minutes without losing any battery life from full charge and with the pencil cover I went for makes for quite the nice addition to my Logitech combo touch case. I wasn‚Äôt sure how to feel at first with spending nearly 130 dollars for this but with how fast Amazon delivered it and I could just use it right out of the box I definitely say this is worth it and continues to be if you are an artist. I drew an astronaut in procreate and the double tap feature to go through my recent tools, color palettes, etc make this just an easy process for productivity and flow. I really didn‚Äôt expect this but having it is definitely worth it. My only gripes are the price and that it is not included in the price of the IPad Pros because even if you‚Äôre like me and primarily use your ipad for media consumption it‚Äôs still a very useful accessory to have in the multitude of accessories you will inevitably buy with the IPad. Considering how often it feels to naturally use this pencil it is very worth the money for the investment. Highly highly recommend this device.

title: Apple Pencil 2: Improved, better but still not perfect

text: I'm not saying this pen isn't good, it's still very good, arguably the best pen for the iPad Pro - the thing is, apple stuff makes apples. But it's not perfect. title: The best on the market
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2022
text: The pencil is awesome for drawing. I love using it with Procreate.I am not as impressed with the writing aspect of it, but I think this is more because the limits of Apple's software than a defect of the pencil itself, but since Apple makes all of it I am still going to take off a star. The problem is a lot of times I will be writing something like an Acronym and it will insist on spell correcting it, or I will attempt to write a period and get a comma. I then end up pulling the keyboard out to fix it, because I get frustrated with the pencil after a few attempts. I would also like to see more gestures, like one to make a new line, etc. Don't even try to write a URL with it. that will be an exercise in futility.I hope there are improvements to the writing software because it feels like it could have a lot of potential, but ends up causing frustration.

title: Works well and what not.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2022
text: Works like I expected it to. I got it for drawing, digital journaling, and some basic stylus stuff. It serves its purpose well. It‚Äôs heavy in a good way and I like the material it‚Äôs made of. It takes a sec to get used to but once you‚Äôve got the hang of it it‚Äôs really comfortable.Only problem I have is that I - think - it may be used. I didn‚Äôt inspect it much when I got it because it looked fine and I‚Äôd ordered it new. I had to look at it more up close when I got a cover for it and noticed a really tiny scuff on the top of it. I hadn‚Äôt dropped it at any point ( I use my iPad on my bed only and am extremely careful ) so I don‚Äôt know what happened there. Maybe it was just dropped during packaging idk.I also watched it‚Äôs battery drop 4% within the span of maybe .5s while it wasn‚Äôt in use. Not sure if that was a problem with the battery health indicator on my iPad or the pencil. It does seem to drain sorta fast but not always. When I got suspicious of it I ran a stopwatch ( for 36 hours by accident. Meant to do 24. Oops ) and the battery wasn‚Äôt too bad then. I wanted to return it but I‚Äôm conflicted AF because outside of that it works fine and I don‚Äôt feel like shipping it back nor waiting for a new one to reach me. Guess I‚Äôll just be expecting to purchase another if this one dies.Overall, I think the Apple Pencil 2 is dope and I would recommend getting it if you want to draw or write. Is it worth purchasing as a random stylus when you only watch Youtube and play games ? Eh. I did find myself reaching for it when I was playing SDV, but if I didn‚Äôt need it for the other things I wouldn‚Äôt even think to purchase it. Cost too damn much.

title: Pretty good. For $120 I'm not impressed tho.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 24, 2022
text: It's fantastic instrument with a couple of flaws.1. It needs to be charged.2. It's too heavy and it's rear balanced.Okay, I don't actually mind having to charge it, it's easy enough that it doesn't impact me much. I do hope that Apple pencil 3 or 4 loses the battery though. If only to reduce the weight...Which is the bigger issue for me. It weighs a pretty substantial .73 oz.Doesn't sound like much does it?For comparison a normal pencil weighs between .2 and .3 oz.Most pens weigh between .3 and .5 oz.It's even heavier than some half inch thick markers, while still being only slightly thicker than a pencil. Which for many will mean they will want to add a grip. Even further increasing the weight.Combine that with the fact it is balanced more towards the eraser than the tip, and well... it's a bit awkward.Will it bother you though?Probably not, most people don't mind. Some people don't even notice.If your an artist though, especially one used to regularly weighted styluses or wood pencils, charcoal. Or anything else under .4 oz.Then yeah you will probably notice. And you probably won't like it at first.Anyways...Overall I still like it. It isn't so heavy that you can't use it. And all the positives of it are still nice. But remember AP3 is probably coming out soon. You may want to wait and see if it's an improvement.

title: Amazon Warehouse Purchase (Artist)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 22, 2020
text: The Apple Pencil is great and is my favorite way to draw digitally. The Apple Pencil 2 has a nice satin/matte finish, a nice change from the previous gloss finish. Wireless charging is one of the biggest changes and might be the only flimsy reason to upgrade from the previous version, because you have to also upgrade your iPad to use the Apple Pencil 2.Extra:I just happened to get the opportunity to upgrade from the first generation Apple Pencil and iPad and it‚Äôs nice. Worth the upgrade? I don‚Äôt really think so. If I didn‚Äôt have the chance to sell my old set and get a little help to upgrade I wouldn‚Äôt have (the wireless charging and magnetic feature is so nice though üòÜ).Bought this from the Amazon Warehouse for a hundred bucks, listed as like new with slight damage to packaging. Also upgraded to the new iPad Pro through Amazon (brand spankin‚Äô new). First time buying something in this price range on here so I was pretty anxious.I pushed through the anxiety and clung onto the belief that if you read the descriptions carefully and do your research you get exactly what you want. Had ordered enough from Amazon to know packages from the U.S. get to me one hundred percent of the time. I weighed everything I could think of in my head then decided.It works perfectly, everything is ‚Äúlike new‚Äù No damage to the actual item. I normally don‚Äôt like buying previously opened items cause I like the ‚ÄúNew, fresh, this is mine, I opened you first‚Äù feeling, but I didn‚Äôt want to shell out the twenty-something extra than what the first generation Apple Pencil cost.Extra Part II:I dove into the Apple drawing set up cause I thought it was a good alternative to a Cintiq at the time. I love the portability and precision of the iPad and pencil just a great over all drawing experience after putting on a matte screen protector of course. File support and apps will only get better, don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever change from this digital drawing set up. It‚Äôs just like picking up a digital sketchbook, it goes anywhere an analog sketchbook and pencil can.There‚Äôs so many options for digital display drawing tables now, compared to when the first generation Apple Pencil came out. Weigh your options and do your research, the Apple Pencil may not be for you. (Wow I really overthought this review üòÖ)

text: I used to have the gen 1 Apple Pencil on my old regular iPad 7, Until I upgraded to the iPad Air 4th Generation and it required to Gen 2  Apple Pencil, I also got the Logitech Folio case which actually uses the smart connector so it never needs charging, protects the iPad, and has a light up keyboard with glass touchpad. The 2nd Gen Apple Pencil is much more accurate than the first, I use ProCreate and am an artist and I can draw anything that is only limited by my imagination. It is literally like drawing on real paper other than you can add special effects and other things like that. title: Much more than a normal stylus

It has to charge because it has functions like switching between eraser and brush tools by simply double tapping the pencil‚Äôs side. The writing/experience also feels VERY smooth and natural. I feel I have massive amount of control over the tool and it never fights me or glitches out on the surface.If you have the excess cash, this is a premium product and it‚Äôs very good, so only thing I can suggest is that you see if you can get hands-on with one of these bad boys before buying. This way you can make a distinction on wether or not you think the price is worth the value.

title: It has no right being this good
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 4, 2022
text: Okay, long time PC user with huge frustration for Apple's practices, also I'm an artist.  The fact that this pencil + ipad that I have (which in total was like $700 in total) is almost as good as a $2000 wacom tablet is irritating and it's making me into an apple fan girl.  Next off the grip.  It's a pencil.  It feels like a heavy pencil, and I had no idea that I needed this in my life for quick sketches.  Not to mention it's so smooth but somehow has a slight grip to it, so it's not going to go sliding out of your hands, and it somehow just feels amazing to hold.  Oh and it's supposed to hang on the side of the ipad.  Probably just keeps it there but any heavy/sharp movements will take this thing off, right?  No, heck no.  This thing is more secure than my bank account password.  I want to hate it, I really really do.  I've disliked Apple practices for so long, but it's just so good that I can't.  And now I'm thinking of getting an iphone next time I upgrade to a new phone.

title: Worthy of the upgrade from Apple Pencil 2
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020
text: The Good:-Pairs instantly with IPad 11 Pro-Easy charging on side of IPad-Comfortable to hold-Writes flawlessly-Good balanceThe Bad:-A bit expensiveThe Bottom Line:I use my Apple Pencil 2 everyday as I take notes with my IPad Pro 11. The Apple Pencil 2 is a definite upgrade to the Apple Pencil 1 almost just because you can charge the pencil by attaching it to your IPad. This feature alone makes the Apple Pencil worth buying. The Apple Pencil 2 also has no lag and write flawlessly. It is very comfortable to hold. The only downside is the pencil is a bit expensive but that‚Äôs common for most Apple products. Overall, I would recommend the Apple Pencil 2 if you have a new version of the IPad Pro.

title: Opens a new world of interaction on iPad
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2021
text: I love this thing. If you have the right hardware for it (I have a 2020 iPad Air) then this will open up a whole new world of iPad use to you. I always drew on paper and never enjoyed art on tablets. Now I can draw on my iPad and it feels as natural as drawing on paper. And because the web is now the same size as it is on regular computers now, it can sometimes be hard to hit small links on web pages. The Apple Pencil lets me more easily navigate around web pages and hit those tiny boxes to close ads.I find myself using the pencil instead of my finger for almost everything on the iPad now. Being able to write directly in text boxes in any app is awesome. It takes about a day for the iPad to learn your handwriting and get what you're writing correct on the first try but once it learns your handwriting the Scribble feature works great.Of course there are times when using the keyboard or just navigating with your fingers is more natural but it's always great to have this pencil for art and for casual use as well. It's an accessory I thought I would only use for drawing but I use it more and more for just about everything now. The fact that it never runs out of battery and magnetically attaches to the side of my iPad makes it so I never have to remember to bring it with me because it's just a part of the iPad now.I would recommend this to anyone. It's not just for artists.

title: Finally got my Apple Pencil after the iPad Pro! worth the extra wait
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2020
text: So I've had the IPad Pro 11" and Apple Pencil 2 since March, honestly, I've only had good experiences. The new IPad Pro  makes the old one's bezels look ugly and thick. I haven't had any bending issues and I keep my iPads in cases anyway as they end up in my bag with tonnes of other crap that could scratch it.The Apple Pencil 2 really brings the IPad Pro out of it's shell though! The wireless charging is a godsend, no more silly 'Pencil dagger', and it gives the case-less among us the ability to keep the Pencil attached without needing a case! I've read issues of metal dust sticking to the magnet part of the Pencil 2, but I haven't experienced this personally!I used mine, on average, an hour a day I'd say? Still no issues in the few months months I've had it, I prefer the matte texture over the shiny plastic of the old Pencil.The Pencil 2 also has the 'Double tap' feature on the flat side, which is incredibly useful if you're an artist, I use this a lot in Procreate to switch between brushes and my eraser, but also works in Affinity Designer etc!UPDATE:I have used this item for a few weeks now and I can affirm that there is no better stylus sold by any manufacturer. The input is smooth, there is virtually no lag compared to other stylus. The 9ms response time absolutely destroyed the 20ms response time on the surface pro I had. And the gripe I still had for the Apple Pencil is that the tip is fragile and can get cracked when you drop it. And the other one, is these are just so EXPENSIVE. If you have a tight budget I'd recommend you getting it during school opening or some sort of discount.This is a great product, though I'd suggest the pen to be longer and less pricier. I would definitely recommend this to my friends and family.

title: Amazon sold me a used one!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2022
text: I ordered this Apple Pencil in anticipation for my new IPad Air 4 back in March 2021. It was marked as ‚Äúnew‚Äù, I paid full price ($130). It worked fantastically for most of the next 17 months. When the pencil was not in my hand, it was attached to the side of my iPad Air 4. It kept a 100% charge all the time when I wasn‚Äôt using it. I draw in Procreate, Illustrator, and Photoshop and I am an avid note taker so I‚Äôm always aware of the battery level of both devices.I always plugged my iPad in every night to charge or at my desk first thing in the morning while I worked. I always checked the Pencil. If it was ever detached for whatever reason, I connected it and observed it was at or near 100% every time. A few minutes later it was back to a full charge.Fast forward to August 2022.  The Apple Pencil suddenly stopped charging. Over the next few days, it failed to charge and died for the first time. It would intermittently charge. Every few days, it appeared to charge to 100% and seemed to be fine. A few days of sporadic use I would notice the Apple Pencil was not charging (I still kept the Pencil attached and the iPad charged). Then magically it would charge again after forgetting the Pencil and reconnecting several times. Then it would sporadically not maintain a charge.I was busy with a lot of important projects during this time so this was low priority in my life. Finally at the last week of September it refused to charge at all. It would charge enough to connect via Bluetooth (only briefly) then disconnect.I took it and my iPad to the local Best Buy (an Apple Authorized Service Provider) and they diagnosed it with a bad battery that would not charge. The tech asked me when I purchased the Pencil and I indicated ‚ÄúMarch 2021‚Äù so he was checking for any warranty that may be active. He checked the Serial Number against an Apple database and told me it was originally purchased in January 2021.I bought a new Pencil and got a used Pencil? It seemed to work fine for over a year. But I‚Äôm left wondering why it suddenly stopped charging? What could‚Äôve been wrong with it to have the Pencil last for so long then stop working? Are Apple Pencils notorious for just not being a good product?Granted, I had the device for one year and a number of months but I did not expect it to crap out on me so quickly. I have a 15 year old Wacom stylus and tablet that still work. I have an iPhone 6S Max that still works (not my daily driver, but still). My 37 year old NES works like it‚Äôs 1985. I take great care of my technology.I took care of it and followed the directions (especially didn‚Äôt get it wet or feed it after midnight). I took it on vacation this summer and it stayed in the room. Not even around water or sand. Yet here was a $130 aluminum and plastic stick that was useless. Like a fool, I did not purchase an Apple Care plan for the Pencil (my mistake). And it was apparently used when I bought it. Amazon lied.I spent $130 on another one at Best Buy that day (much to the chagrin from my wife) and I shouldn‚Äôt have had to do that. I could see if I treated it poorly and did not keep it charged but that was not the case.Amazon sold me a used Pencil that may have had a defect. I double checked my order to make sure I did not buy a refurbished or used Pencil (I did not). And since it worked for almost 18 months‚Ä¶probably nothing I can do.

text: Just buy the pencil new. I tried to be cheap & get the Used, but it's absolute bs. First of all, if was sent to me in a plastic mf bag with only the little instruction & safety pamphlets. Then I finally get it out to use with my new iPad Pro, the 2021 version and OF COURSE the stupid thing doesn't work. It pairs with the iPad, it charges with the iPad, it just doesn't WORK.UPDATE: Scratch that, just go straight to the freaking Apple store!! So since the $80 Used pencil didn't work, I went ahead & bought the $100 one. Overnight shipping is great, which is the only upside to this entire experience because the "new" one was broken as well!!!!! First of all, I think they sent me a USED PENCIL IN A NEW BOX!!! This pencil had the same/similar scuff marks as the used one!! Including little dents on the end of the freaking pencil!! AAAAANNNDDDD it still didn't work!! Charged to 100%, connects to the iPad, tap gestures work, made sure the tip was tight, bluetooth was on, restarted the iPad‚Äî NOTHING. I was starting to think my iPad was the defective one! I ended up buying a $30 knockoff and it works PERFECTLY. Maybe next paycheque, i'll walk into Apple & get the real pencil (the knockoff doesn't have pressure sensitivity & i WAS using iPad to draw) but right now i'm just grateful to the knockoff. Maybe amazon isn't the best place to get CERTAIN tech. I didn't trust it enough to get the iPad from here, I probably should've just gotten the pencil from the Apple store (app) at the same time i purchased the iPad.

title: Worth. Every. Penny.

text: Not that Apple needs another great review on this but I was quite honestly dumbstruck by how well it works. As a heavy Wacom Intuos user, as well as several of their older models, I‚Äôve been using a drawing tablet & stylus for a long time (15+ years) & thought it‚Äôd be about the same experience, but I was dead wrong. The Apple Pencil is WAY more pressure sensitive & you can be a lot more precise with it because of that.The Apple Pencil is not too heavy, either, but it is pretty narrow so if you‚Äôre used to that fat Wacom stylus you may want to add a rubber grip of some kind. Those can interfere with charging them though, so something to think about.Using the Apple Pencil with your iPad and Sidecar on your Mac is a little too quirky; the connection & the ability to see what you‚Äôre drawing in real time through that connection (wired in or not) totally depends on how fast your internet speed is. I just have DSL so it‚Äôs too slow to use, but I‚Äôll try it again when we upgrade our internet. Fair warning for those of you who want to use it in place of your Wacom drawing tablet.Generally speaking, I‚Äôm so glad I finally caved on this. I LOVE using it & find every excuse to play with it, from note taking with Goodnotes to doodling in Procreate or having fun in the lite Adobe apps. I actually don‚Äôt know anyone who hasn‚Äôt been pleased with the Apple Pencil & I know quite a few that have bought it. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

title: I thought there was something wrong, but I figured it out
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
text: This is so cool. I love how it‚Äôs magnetically attracted to the top of the iPad Pro and then charges. It pairs automatically the first time, but I think I had to go into my settings to turn on my Bluetooth. So if it doesn‚Äôt work right away, that might be why. It also stopped working and wouldn‚Äôt write anymore. Thank goodness it was an easy fix! The tip of the pen had loosened on top, as if were coming unscrewed. I thought it was made like that for calibration, but nope! Just screwed it back down and voila, it worked! It looks really sleek and I love that I don‚Äôt have to plug it in! My favorite part is that I can write like I would with any writing tool. After downloading several drawing and note taking apps, I played around with simple adjustments. It‚Äôs great to go effortlessly between thin and thicker lines, transparency, and different instruments. The colored pencil shows up as a very nice textured-look, the pen is an even distribution of color and line, and the marker is great in the transparency mode. I especially like how I can lay my hand on the iPad when writing and drawing. I‚Äôm sure others have already experienced this before now with previous iPad and Apple Pencil releases, but it‚Äôs revolutionary for me. I also got a iPad Pro case that has a tray to hold your pen

title: Is it worth the money?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2021
text: I got the Apple Pencil for use with my iPad Air 4.  I like the Apple Pencil, I really do.  It works great for my note taking I do for work.  I don't really draw, but I tried that briefly and it seemed to work well too.I think the big question is, is it worth the full retail price?  I think the answer is, it depends.  If you like to draw on an iPad then I think it's probably absolutely worth it.  The pressure sensitivity seems to work well and it's comfortable to hold and use.If you just want it for note taking and a little doodling now and then, then it's probably not worth the full price to you.  This could also depend on how many notes you are taking though.  It might be absolutely worth it if you are a student and take tons of notes, but in general, most people probably don't need to spend the money on the pencil.If you aren't drawing and just are focused on note taking I would look at the Logitech pencil.  It doesn't have the pressure sensitivity, but it should work fine for note taking.I gave the Apple Pencil 4 stars because I don't think it's a must have accessory and I think it's a little over priced for what it does.  I would just consider what you truly need it for before purchasing.  If you don't really draw then wait for a sale or watch for it on Amazon Warehouse like I did or consider the Logitech pencil.

title: Works fine but could use some improvements
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
text: I got iPad Pro and Apple Pencil 2 to teach remote classes. Overall it actually works unlike other pens on other touchscreens I tried, but there are some things that could be improved.The battery life is too short. After two classes in a row (2.5 hours) it just stopped.After few months the pencil would not pair any more and stopped. Apple did replace it under AppleCare it but not without inquisition about damage first and wanted credit card in case of damage to ship replacement. The shipping took too long so I bought a spare on Amazon, I figured if one died it may happen again and I cannot afford that.  Then the return instructions wanted the bad one pretty quick or else they would charge the card. Not good. They confirmed that the return was received but not if it was accepted without a charge. Months later the repair status is still that a technician will look at it soon.The pencil keeps falling off the iPad and getting lost. This is really bad. There should be a way to locate it - buzz or ring or at least some indicator on the iPad that the pencil is nearby. Regardless if it is paired or not, I have two, and only one can be paired at a time.Mostly it draws fine but occasionally the line does get interrupted and or it makes extra long straight lines or changes the tool when when I touch it by hand (palm rejection not working quite right). Also, the tip keeps getting loose then it stops working.Finally, I never managed to make the tap to change tool feature do anything.

title: Love it!!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 24, 2020
text: I had a 1st Gen pencil that I loved and was heartbroken when I found that getting a new iPad this year meant I had to pass that to my mom (to use on her iPad) and fork up over $100 for a new one.  I luckily found Amazon had a slightly lower price, I had some money in my gift card to offset costs AND they were going to ship it to me way faster than Apple was (they had a 3 week lead time).  Yay....and I love it.  I have been designing fonts for years and my iPad is my go to machine to start that process.  Plus, I use Astropad a lot to work from my desktop and having a pencil is vital.The matte finish of this pencil is SO much better than the slippery previous pencil - though since I tend to hold pencils pretty hard I have gotten a silicon protector to prevent hand fatigue.  I don't find myself using the double-tap feature much, but glad that it is there as an option.  I love that you can easily recharge it, because I am often caught mid-work when the darn thing stops responding.  Having the cable, or sticking it out of the iPad, was always a BAD idea with the previous version (I almost snapped the darn thing off once).  This model recharged super fast, and easily....Wish it was roughly the same cost as the previous, but it is still the best out there for working on an iPad that is precise and without lag.

text: To say I am not an artist would be a serious understatement. Having said that, I am finding so many uses for this I never dreamed of before. My only real problem is that it‚Äôs been so long since I actually wrote anything with a pen or pencil, it will require some practice on my part to make my handwriting legible to iPadOS in order to take advantage of the handwriting capture/translate functions. That is hardly the fault of the pencil, though.I have seen that the battery charge on the Pencil does not last as long as I thought it would. I‚Äôve seen the charge go down 20-25% just overnight if I forget to set it on the charging side of the iPad. I don‚Äôt really know if that‚Äôs expected or not, but I have learned to keep it charging when not actually using it, which suits my needs just fine.Did I *need* this device to make full use of my iPad? Of course not. However, I will use it to the best of my ability and hopefully learn a few new tricks along the way. :)

title: IPad Necessity
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 14, 2021
text: I ordered this refurbished through a secondhand seller, and firstly want to say that it cam in a condition that was as if it were brand new.  If you have an IPad that you use as a productivity device, this is an essential accessory.  2 years ago I had the Ipad air 2019 and the Logitech crayon (as the air only supported the first gen Apple Pencil at the time).  While the Logitech Crayon was effective for writing, and did create a desirable experience, this is far superior, as this is better integrated and more customizable to your needs.  The writing experience as well is just *chef‚Äôs kiss* perfection.  The only con I have is that despite its functional integration with the iPad, there still isn‚Äôt much of a means of securing it with the iPad.  The magic keyboard has no holster for it, and the magnet on the side is insufficient when putting the unit into a bag.  The pencil always falls away into the dark caverns within my bag.  Otherwise, 10/10 would recommend to a friend.

title: Almost perfect, but 1 major flaw.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 28, 2019
text: Finally splurged for this pencil after using soft tipped, non-accurate stylus‚Äôs for years. Below is my feedback. Note that I have an iPad Pro 3rd generation tablet.- accuracy is excellent. Regular cheap stylus‚Äôs are difficult to select particular letters of words, and they aren‚Äôt good at copying and pasting. Apple Pencil does this extremely well!- controlling YouTube fast forward or back is so much easier using this pencil vs my fat finger.- pencil feels so comfortable in your hand. To me, the perfect diameter.- pencil length is also great as it allows me to reach everywhere on my iPad screen.- the tip of the pencil is pointy but smooth. Won‚Äôt damage your screen if you don‚Äôt have a glass protective cover. And, the thinness of the tip fits perfectly between letters when you want to make a selection.-  battery lasts a very long time.-  recharging the pencil by magnetically attaching to the top of your iPad makes the process so easy!- you will not be able to swipe up using the pencil to bring up open apps nor can you access control center from the upper right hand corner. I can live with this but I hope a software update in the future addresses this.- now the major flaw! You can‚Äôt use this pencil on your iPhone. I have an 11 pro max and it‚Äôs so disappointing that Apple didn‚Äôt make the pencil work on iPhone. For the cost of this item I find that to be unacceptable! Apple, if you are reading these reviews make the next generation pencil work with iPhone!!!However, I still highly recommend this item for use with your iPad.

title: Great for drawing or everyday iPad use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 9, 2021
text: I purchased this Apple Pencil mostly for drawing, which is works great. No complaints. It holds a charge REALLY well, actually surprised me after using the pencil over an hour I attached it to the iPad and it said charged 100% which was nice.After opening the pencil and using it for the first time, within 30 minutes I thought I had broke it. I couldn‚Äôt get it to work on the iPad at all and I was certain I messed something up. I looked and actually the tip of the pencil had become slightly unscrewed and I just tightened it back up and it went back to working perfectly fine. I have not had to mess with it again.There are no buttons on the pencil (it charges by magnetizing to the side of the iPad) but it does have a feature where you double tap the pencil and you can set it to do different things, for example, I have mine set to switch between drawing tool and eraser while I‚Äôm drawing.Side note the pencil does also work great with just every day touch use! It is not just for drawing, I use it almost every time I have to use the touchscreen or playing games etc. to keep fingerprints off.

title: Great Battery, Excellent Quality!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 9, 2021
text: My new favorite thing! As someone who recently got into digital art via iPad (using Procreate on an iPad Air 4) this is an absolute godsend. I purchased this when the price was around $99 and I don‚Äôt regret a thing. It‚Äôs obviously overpriced for the item itself since you are paying for name brand, but this Apple Pencil is a BIG step from the last, and, in my opinion, worth the splurge. The pairing is easy,, the flat side of the pencil is magnetic and will hold onto the side of your iPad for dear life. The battery on the pencil itself is AMAZING. I‚Äôll use my iPad to take notes in class, and even after using the pencil for that time, it will only be at around 95%. I haven‚Äôt seen it go below 90 because of how convenient the charging is! I‚Äôve been using it for a couple weeks now, and I haven‚Äôt felt the need to get new tips for it. I‚Äôm not sure if there‚Äôs a recommended time to change it out as to not damage the screen, but so far it draws and writes as smoothly as it did when I first got it. Feels natural to hold, and soft to touch because of the matte finish. HIGHLY recommend for artists or note-takers on the newer iPads.

title: flawless workflow integration worth the upgrade
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 31, 2019
text: Visually there seems to be not too much of a difference from the first release of the apple pencil but this iteration 2.0 is definitely worth the upgrade! Charging and connecting is so super easy now. The pencil reacts super well for drawing, sketching, drafting and to me as an interior architect especially well with autoCAD, morpholio and other drawing apps. The tab on the pen to bring the eraser to front makes my workflow so much more enjoyable. Although it doesn't seem like much that Apple has added one flat side to the overall round pencil design it makes such a huge difference in holding comfort. The fact that it attaches magnetically to the side of my iPad pro is super helpful as I don't have to look for the pencil any more. It is right were it belongs to be while not being in the way. Absolute buying recommendation if you are a heavy graphics designer or even just a casual user. It is also just a whole lot of fun to interact with the pencil on the iPad!

title: Perfect for beginners and experts alike!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 23, 2021
text: I decided to purchase this Apple Pencil after I had bought my iPad Air at my local Target. Let me just say, this thing does not disappoint! I've been getting into digital art lately, and it's perfect. The accuracy is amazing, the pressure sensitivity is spot on, and the battery lasts for hours on end! Not only that, but they integrated a magnetic connector onto the tops of the newer iPad Airs and Pros, so all you have to do to charge it is pop it onto the top of your iPad, and you're ready to go! No need for any cables whatsoever. And you can even double tap the flat side of the Pencil to perform a shortcut of your choosing (such as undo, redo, switch between pen and eraser, etc.) It connects via Bluetooth, which makes it a breeze to set up. Overall, I would highly recommend this Apple Pencil to beginner and expert artists, or anyone who wants to doodle, take notes, and/or simply wants a good stylus for their iPad.

title: Very good stylus, but a couple gotchas
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 20, 2019
text: First off, the stylus is great for taking notes, marking up documents, and just doodling. Very low latency, the matte finish is a much needed upgrade over the glossy material used in the last generation, and it's flat edge makes it easier to just leave on the table. The magnets and wireless charging are definite upgrades.Now, let's get into why I had to buy the new version. I recently got one of the new iPad Pros to replace an older iPad and I still had the first generation Apple Pencil. Me being naive, I thought the old one would work fine with the brand new iPad. Wrong. Even if you have a lightning to USB-C cable and the lightning-lightning adapter, you still can't pair the old one to the new iPad. This is very annoying, but I can't say that I'm surprised. We all know why Apple has made the old Apple pencil obsolete.One more complaint is that you can't do gestures with this pencil. This is a software issue, but it's still part of the experience of using the pencil. For example, you can't bring up the multitasking menu, you can't swipe down to view notifications or control center, the only gesture you can do is swipe up from a corner to take a screenshot. Very annoying that I can't perform these types of things with the pencil.4/5 still works great and got $72 for my first gen pencil so not that bad.

title: Does exactly what it says and does it well
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 20, 2021
text: It does exactly what it says and does it well.Most students at my school use this with their iPads to take notes. I even see almost half of the other Math and Computer Science majors using this or something like it.I personally prefer typing, but I could definitely see using it as a secondary note-taking apparatus...Also, it makes drawing *much* easier.Make sure you buy a paper-feeling screen protector. The regular iPad screen is much too smooth for serious writing or drawing. (not the "Paperlike" brand - that's garbage *)I would recommend ELECOM Pencil-Feel Screen Protector (either for Drawing or Writing). It makes it much easier to write and doesn't impact visibility much at all (not even the "rough" one).The only downside of these (especially the "rough" one) is that they wear out the tips faster. Not bad because three replacement tips are only like $25*Online consensus is the "Paperlike" screen protector is an over-rated scam. I would stay away.

The matte finish is also much nicer somehow, it feels better in the hand, without feeling slippery. I love it.

title: I thought there was something wrong, but I figured it out
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
text: This is so cool. I love how it‚Äôs magnetically attracted to the top of the iPad Pro and then charges. It pairs automatically the first time, but I think I had to go into my settings to turn on my Bluetooth. So if it doesn‚Äôt work right away, that might be why. It also stopped working and wouldn‚Äôt write anymore. Thank goodness it was an easy fix! The tip of the pen had loosened on top, as if were coming unscrewed. I thought it was made like that for calibration, but nope! Just screwed it back down and voila, it worked! It looks really sleek and I love that I don‚Äôt have to plug it in! My favorite part is that I can write like I would with any writing tool. After downloading several drawing and note taking apps, I played around with simple adjustments. It‚Äôs great to go effortlessly between thin and thicker lines, transparency, and different instruments. The colored pencil shows up as a very nice textured-look, the pen is an even distribution of color and line, and the marker is great in the transparency mode. I especially like how I can lay my hand on the iPad when writing and drawing. I‚Äôm sure others have already experienced this before now with previous iPad and Apple Pencil releases, but it‚Äôs revolutionary for me. I also got a iPad Pro case that has a tray to hold your pen,

title: Beware of buying this for a student who has an iPad case
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 22, 2022
text: I am sure the Apple Pencil is nice, but beware that if you have a big rugged case on your iPad (as mandated by my daughter's school) the Pencil is basically worthless. Every time my daughter needs to charge the pencil or use it, she needs to take the case off her iPad, which is a big ordeal. And even if you buy an external charger, it doesn't work because you have to touch the pencil to the iPad charge pad to sync it. This is the most poorly designed Apple product I have ever seen for students. You are better off buying the Generation 1 Pencil or a cheaper third-party version.

title: Great successor to the first!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on June 12, 2019
text: The drawing experience on this is exactly like traditional paper and pencil. Refresh rate is instant, and pressure sensitivity is so realistic. I do wish it came with extra tips but not a huge deal. Apple is getting stingier and stingier as their revenues taper so I'm not surprised. Apple brand replacement tips are relatively affordable.Love the weight of the pencil, and how stable it is when you put it down. Never rolls off the table. Charging it is effortless and battery life is great. Makes it more of a must have for the iPad Pro (2018 version). They really got it right this time. I would recommend getting a silicone sleeve with a tip cover for it, mostly for scratch/drop protection. They sell some that don't affect the functionality. I dropped it once while carrying my iPad underneath my arm. I accidentally nudged the pencil off the magnet and it fell on the floor. Another option would be to get one of those singular pockets you strap around the iPad case and hold your pencil in. (They have adhesive versions you attach to your iPad case, but I don't like the idea of permanently adhering something like that. Go for the elastic strap one.) A lot of people recommend the paperlike screen protector or a generic matte version, because it improves the experience of drawing. However I can honestly say that writing directly on the screen feels just fine, won't scratch your screen, and does not wear down the tips nearly as fast as those will! It's like writing on very fine sandpaper.

title: Just Don't Buy Used
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 3, 2023

Item itself arrived in original packaging sans plastic wrap and charged just fine. Went to go use it in Procreate (see image) and noticed my lines would skip in certain areas. Originally I thought it might be the iPad itself but when I use my finger in that same area it registers just fine.I've spent the last 4 hours with Apple Support troubleshooting different things and now have to spend the $20 I saved from buying a used pencil on buying new tips, since that's the last step before I'm out another $120 to replace it.

title: The most expensive pencil in the world, plus - was it "new" Amazon?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 10, 2019
text: Bought this in March 2019 along with an iPad Pro.  Both items were sold by Amazon as "new."  This past week the pencil died.  No big deal, there's a one year warranty.  However, Apple informed me that the warranty on my pencil's serial number expired already.  The Apple warranty department is reviewing this as I was able to produce an Amazon receipt showing that Amazon sold this to me as "new", but they told me this was not the first time they've seen this.  I think for me, this is the final straw with Amazon, coupled with reports of them banning books based on political viewpoints, I'm done giving Amazon my Prime money.  As for the pencil, it makes using the iPad easier, but shame on Apple for milking $130 from people for something that should cost no more than $50.  Incidentally, we checked the serial number on the iPad.  At least Amazon got that right.

text: *Great tool, just use caution when buying used.*This pencil is amazing. I purchased it to go with my iPad Pro so I can use Procreate.I had purchased this in "Used -Very Good" condition from an amazon seller. The listing said "packaging may be damaged, product is in like new condition". But I think they sold me whatever they had handy, the original packaging was in great shape, but the tip of the pencil was chewed up. Looks like it was probably dropped on something hard. I noticed when I drew something, the pencil would "miss" at certain places. That's when I noticed the condition of the tip. Thankfully, replacement tips can be purchased. I contacted Amazon to see if they'd just sent a set of tips, but they said they could not do that. After a little back and forth, I finally asked if they could refund me for the price of the tips and they happily agreed. So a big shout out for a great customer service team.

title: An incredible form shift from the first generation Apple Pencil
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on April 2, 2020
text: The newest iteration of the Apple Pencil is a genuine improvement over the first generation. While all of the technology within remains the same (as far as sensitivities and detection), the simple change in form is enough to warrant upgrading to the new iPad/Apple Pencil combo.The glossy finish of the original pencil is replaced by a matte texture which allows for a better grip. The flat edge serves a dual purpose. It allows for a magnetic edge for easy attachment to the iPad for charging/pairing (MUCH improved over the lighting port "antenna" charging of old), and it also acts as a capacitive touch "button" to change between two tools (like a writing tool and its eraser). While the internals of the pencil remain largely the same, the neural engine on the new iPad reduces input lag down to an unnoticeable minimum which makes the new pencil FEEL like it got an overhaul as well.Overall, the new pencil is quite enjoyable to write with; so much so that it makes the old pencil feel like a prototype. Whereas the 1st generation pencil was innovative for its time, the new pencil has succeeded in BOTH the form AND function. Truly a technological feat.

title: Left-handed and loving it.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2019
text: To be honest, this pen is probably my favorite utencil. Prior to my iPad purchase, I was using (and absolutely loved) my Surface Pro 3. The pen was smooth and worked for all of my art needs. I still have my pro and still use it, but due to it's age, using the device without being plugged in is no longer an option. I digress; this pen is amazing. There is a learning curve however; one must learn how to adjust the sensitivity to ones general writing styles and pressures.I'm left-handed, and sometimes that can cause some major issues with art tablets and digital work spaces. This was no problem at all. Not to mention the shape is perfectly fit for any writing style. I did need to learn how to utilize the double click features and other gestures that can be done, but nothing was out of my immediate comfort zone. Of course, I am not proud of spending that amount of money... but it was worth every cent. If you are getting an iPad pro without a pen, that's okay... but if you do any writing, drawing, or any sort of stylus use, I urge you to get the apple pen.

title: What you don't know about Apple defective products.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2022
text: I bought a defective Apple Pencil probably for about $100. It worked until the first charge ran out and then it refused to charge. I was busy so I didn't call apple support until I owned the pencil for about 3 weeks. They talked me thru resetting it, and it charged. But it only worked for about a week. Amazon offers no return on defective Apple products - you are sent to Apple support who doesn't care how much time you have to spend talking to them to fix the problem.And remember when you brought that apple product online because you were too busy to go into the store. Well if you are unlucky enough to buy a defective product you can make multiple trips to their apple store in 110+ degree weather. And what sad is they know the store can't even help you with the Apple pencils. The store cant do any trouble shooting that can not be done on the phone.Also If they are sending you to the apple store - make sure the store has one in stock. Because thats really all you are going to the store for. They did offer to replace it, all I have to do is make another trip to the store after they order it. Sorry, we can't ship it to you.Really a trip to the store to fix a problem with a brand new device is like paying for shipping when they send you something that is broken in the first placeI‚Äôve spent time on 3 customer service calls and Apple support team sent me to an apple store in person. But the apple store can‚Äôt do anything else to troubleshoot apple pencils the the online person can. And on top of that they did not even have a replacement pencil which is what was clearly needed.I could have bought a new pencil myself for all of MY time apple has wasted trying to fix their defect.At this point, I‚Äôm entirely insulted by Apples total lack of respect for their customers time. This was supposed to be a brand new product. Not to mention Apple's waste of their own employees time, for the amount of time they paid their employees to give me the run around they could have paid for 2 pencils.I'm normally an Apple lover, but shame on Apple.

title: A fantastic tool for a digital artist, but expensive upkeep.

text: My only issue with this product is that the pen nib wears down frustratingly easily.As a long time digital artist I am no stranger to replacing a pen nib, but it seems like apple could make something a little more resilient for the price point of this device.Though replacement nibs are not too expensive, it does evoke a huge eye-roll to know your funneling that much more money into the Apple corporation after already dropping over a grand on their iPad and required accessories.Otherwise, I am pleased with the function and sensitivity of the Apple Pencil though it's still not quite as precise as a Wacom pen.The portability, versatility, and ease of setup for digital art is the reason I chose the Apple Pencil/iPad combo over a Cintiq, and I certainly don't regret it, but it does hurt to expect to keep opening my wallet for new nibs.

I am sending it back and Amazon is sending another. I will change the review when the other one arrives (hopefully if it‚Äôs  not broken). Oh well ... and there are no extra tips like with the first gen.  That stunk. Sometimes the pencil glitches while using the lasso effect in goodnotes, so you have to repeatedly try.  It didn't glitch with my finger or a friends non-apple pencil ... soooo ... Otherwise, I'm pleased.  The pros far outweigh the cons and it's worth it.

title: A warning to anyone looking to invest
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on June 14, 2021
text: So the product works great, however I‚Äôve already had to buy two of these because both of mine have died on me after only a few months of use. The nibs are fine, the batteries stayed charged, they weren‚Äôt dropped or anything like that but both of them have crapped out on me. I use my  iPad for art, so these things are taken care of as though they‚Äôre fine China, like these are my babies so I‚Äôm always careful with them. However both of them have died now and it‚Äôs frustrating.I bought my first one with my I pad and it only lasted two months before all pressure sensitivity was gone. I use my IPad Pro for artwork, so once that goes these are useless for anything, because you can only achieve hairline strokes after that.Apple won‚Äôt replace them nor repair them, so I was forced to buy a new one. I looked it up online and everyone said they last a while so I though okay maybe I just got a bad one.Well bought a new one, this one in its defense, lasted for almost 5 months, but then died too. These aren‚Äôt cheap, and it‚Äôs becoming really frustrating when you can‚Äôt find any answers and there‚Äôs no help whatsoever from the company themselves outside of just have to replace the pencil.I don‚Äôt know, this is almost $500 already just spent on replacing these pencils. I‚Äôm going to buy this last one and if it dies on me as well, then I‚Äôm going to look into other styluses. I can‚Äôt afford to be buying these things every few months.I guess anyone looking to buy these, just be aware that you may be in for a constant money pit or perhaps I‚Äôm just having horrible luck. Whatever is going on, this is very frustrating and I warn anyone who is looking to invest in one of these to keep it in mind.

title: don't drop it!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2022
text: A: Write with it, store it, and drop it.Q: What are the 3 most common things people do with a pen or pencil?  Apple got 2 out of 3 right on the Apple Pencil. Unfortunately, at $129 a pop, the outside casing is a concern. Don't drop it on a hard surface, ceramic tile for one, because the pretty white outside can crack and probably will. Mine did in two places. The crack starts out as a hairline fracture, looking almost like someone scribbled a small line with a #2 lead pencil. Eventually, it spreads both in length and width so it forms a ridge. My pencil was not 90 days old when this happened.  Shame on Apple engineers. Pencils. Write, store, drop. We do all three, the first two intentionally. Dropping is done accidentally. At $129 they need to be designed to do all 3 well. The current material choice is too brittle and unforgiving.  Apple can do better, and should do better. Until then, buyer beware and check out alternatives. When this one stops working I will not replace it with an Apple Pencil. If you do buy one, don't drop it.

text: If there were competing products for this device, I would quickly consider them, but in evaluating knock-off replacements none of them had the featureset of this pen to even be considered in the realm of competitive. The biggest problem I have with this pen right now is that the battery does not last long enough because I can easily be drawing or writing for hours at a time. And gawd knows you need a case for your iPad, and all the available cases make keeping the pen charged impossible. I'm currently on the hunt for other ways to charge this pen; but damn they need to power this up. Why we need a bluetooth pen is beyond me, sure correction and palm rejection and all that, but come on there has to be a better low-powered way to do these things. Plus the pen for me is just way to dang thick, as I tend to prefer much finer writing utilites, I'm also struggling/learning to translate my style with a much larger tip. I don't like it, but that's just me. Also, at most the pen should priced about half as much as it is, it's current pricepoint just feels greedy. I'm hoping a knock-off can come and implement the features correctly, but I wont hold my breath.

title: I am very sad and upset with this item
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2020
text: Okay, so I bought this apple pencil 2nd generation.It did not have a vinyl sealing to it. To be honest, I did not realize this right away. I was just happy to see it arrive.Well, then I opened up the box to see that it had black markings on it.Then, it came to me, "is this not new?"So I looked up Apple Pencil 2nd Generation Unboxing videos on youtube. They all had vinyl packings on them. Which mine did not have.So I called up Amazon to file a return. I was not happy about this at all. But, the lady at the customer servicr was very nice to lead me through the process. So I decided not to get angry and just have another one sent to me.But, unfortunately, the story does not end here.So I got the new amazon package this morning.I opened the amazon box. But the item did NOT have a packing either.I was not amused. But nonetheless I pulled on the plastic to slide the box out of the outer pocket.There was another surprise for me there.When I pulled on the plastic, I could see the bottom the box, not the top(with the apple instructions and everything).Like, literally, the box had been inserted upsidedown by some unknown person before me. I thought, well clearly this is not a new product.But this was my second time getting the pen. I was tired of waiting and I didn't want to go the UPS store again to return my faulty item. So I decided to take a look at the item.Thinking, " if it was clean, maybe i'll just take it."Ha!But that didnt work out either. They had sent me a apple pencil 1st generation.I feel like its natural to get a bit angry now. I could have been happy with my pencil days ago. Now I have to go through UPS again.I am upset, angry and very very sad.

title: potentially counterfeit?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2023
text: i got the pen on sale for $80 - maybe for good reason. it was sealed new in box, but after using it for a little while i noticed the screen wouldnt respond unless i put on extra pressure. it was difficult to unscrew the tip and when i finally did, the inside was full of black powder, like the rod inside was rubbing off against the inner screw portion of the tip. ive been using apple pencils for a few years now and have never seen this. the tips usually screw on and off with ease and the inner rod remains gold even after wear and tear. maybe just a faulty pen, maybe counterfeit. strange experience. the return was easy though! i went and bought another for full price from t@rget and it works perfectly.

title: Only lasted 4 months!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2021
text: Just ordered and Received on Sept 11th 2020 and it is no longer recognized by my Ipad pro 11. It was working and charged as I took it off and put it back on to check battery status, I than took it off to use it and it wasn't working so I went into my Bluetooth to see it said not connected. I clicked the i "forget device" placed the pencil back onto the device, found the pencil under avaliable devices but it still wouldn't connect I kept getting an error message. I than turned the tablet off and back on tried it again but this time no pencil was found under "devices" or "avaliable devices" I tried this over and over and still the same result. The pencil was fully charged so no reason it should be dead but I figured hey what can it hurt to let it charge for awhile to see if maybe it has a batter issue. Let it charge for 30 minutes and still nothing! 4 months old and already useless!!!! I loved this pencil used it to edit photos, used it when creating designs so helpful but it isn't worth $130 if it is going to break after 4 months! Am going to contact Apple tomorrow to see what they can do about it since I purchased it brand new sealed in the box.

title: Why a 3?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2021
text: It was advertised as less likely to roll, wrong. It rolls right off the table. So level my table. Absolutely! However the advertising that it is less likely to roll is misleading, it just keeps on going - flat side or not. Also the magnetic hold on an iPad is not strong enough to keep the pencil from flying off when you pick the iPad up. So, be careful? Absolutely, but caveat emptor, this pencil may have a lot going for it, but it is still pretty liable to go flying if you are not careful. Word up.

title: Will Die On You With No Solution
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2022
text: After less than a year and hardly many use, following one of apple‚Äôs many updates, my pencil has completely died.Multiple attempts at restarting the iPad, turning off and on Bluetooth, updating or hard restarting, even forgetting existing connections entirely.Nothing. Even attempted some oddball solution someone suggested of wrapping copper wire around it. I get a grey ‚Äòapple pencil‚Äô pop up on the to-, and that‚Äôs it with no change from tapping it, no indication of charge, nothing at all.Considering the thing simply stayed by my desk 99% of the time, for the extortionate price of this product, this is quite inexcusable.At best, they‚Äôre built shoddy, with a battery that‚Äôll fry on you with minor use if you‚Äôre unlucky. Far more likely given apple‚Äôs history, quite frank;y, they‚Äôre built cheap as can be with the full expectation that you will have to pay their outrageous repair fees or just replace their faulty products outright.Save your money, don‚Äôt buy Apple products. Quality has never been their speciality, and this has never been more apparent than now. This thing is junk, and I regret not simply buying a dedicated tablet for my drawing. In the end, I spent more on a worse product, and got screwed over as a result.Learn from my mistakes,.

Terrible quality and now I'll need to buy new nibs for a brand new Pencil.Edit: Apple's own support is now telling me that it is "out of warranty" which means this product is likely over a year old, and has been sitting on shelves or WORSE was used and sold "as new" by Amazon. title: DEFECTIVE, & Apple won't Honor the Warranty if Purchased on Amazon
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 13, 2020
text: Out of the box it wouldn't work, no matter what we tried.  Called Apple Tech. Support and they confirmed it is defective and advised me to take it to the nearest Apple store for replacement, since it has a one-year warranty.  WRONG, Apple won't honor the one-year warranty (I drove to my nearest Apple store explained that Apple Tech. Support sent me there for a replacement and was told, no, Apple won't honor the warranty for products purchased through Amazon).  Don't waste your money on Apple products, I've spent over $6,000.00 in the last five months on Apple desktop, I-Pad, I-Phone XS Max, AirPods Pro and Apple Pencil, and had trouble with every piece of it, requiring at least eighteen calls to tech. support, hours and hours of wasted time and enormous frustration to get their products to work.  Apple has gone straight down the toilet ever since Steve Jobs passed away.  I am seriously considering returning every item that I can get a refund for and going with Samsung replacements.  My Samsung smartphone has performed flawlessly and intuitively ever since I got it four years ago, and hasn't required a single call to Tech. Support.  I've been an Apple fanboy for over 20 years, but after the last five months of frustration and wasted time and energy, I'm not anymore.  You've lost a loyal customer Apple.  Looks like it's time to sell my stock as my experience in the last five months doesn't portend well for this company going forward!!!

title: Keep getting defective pens
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on June 3, 2021
text: The pen I first got had a tip that was stuck on the pen. You couldn't loosen the tip or tighten it, it was stuck. It could charge but couldn't write on the iPad Air 4.Got a replacement pen. It works normally but now there's a new problem with a tip - when I write at a particular part of the tip, the tip is scraping the screen. The tip is defective.I'm not even going to bother asking for another replacement. A defective tip is annoying, but I'm tired of visiting the UPS store to return items so I'm just going to suck it up and deal with it.If you're curious, I'd just get the apple pen 2 in store at a Best Buy or something. That way, you can test the pen directly in store first before you leave - making sure the tip isn't stuck, that it writes smoothly at all angles - even on a screen protector, that it charges, etc.  It's a stress-free no-hassle, compared to buying on Amazon, receiving two defective units and just saying "screw it I'm just gonna deal with it, ugh."

title: Very disappointing
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 12, 2019
text: I recently purchased an IPad Pro 3gen, and a generic stylus pen. I fell in love with the pen but it quit inside of 6 weeks. Since I loved the pen feature I decided to just go ahead and spend $125 more to get what I thought would be a much superior product only to be disappointed. The Apple pen is shaped poorly, it is not a round pen so it doesn‚Äôt roll easily in my hands.  The pen is also very heavy as compared to most writing utensils, and the generic pen I purchased.  The Apple pen does not give me the ability to close pages using the swipe up feature, instead I have to free up a finger/thumb to perform this function instead.  The Apple pen performance is a wee bit better then generic stylus, but for my simple purposes the difference was negligible. The double tap, and sidebar charging features weren‚Äôt worth the swap for comfort generic stylus gave me.  I expected so much more from Apple If I could return the Apple pen and purchase the generic stylus again, I would.

title: Does not work with all new IPads
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2019
text: I purchased this for my daughter to use on her IPad generations 7.  I am a computer consultant, so both my daughter and I know how to set up electronic devices. After trying for an hour to get this to connect to her IPad via Bluetooth my daughter called Apple.  The first phone call she was told to connect the pencil to the right side of her IPad via the magnetic connection and to let it fully charge before trying to connect it to the IPad via Bluetooth.  She was told that during the charging process that the pencil and IPad would connect via Bluetooth automatically.  After letting the pencil fully charge my daughter found out that they still would not connect to each other.  That's when she called Apple the second time.  This time she was told that the Apple Pencil 2 will only work with the IPad Pro, not the IPad generation 7, even though it was a new model.  She was told that she would have to return the Apple Pencil 2 and order the older version Apple Pencil 1 in order for it to work with her IPad.  Nowhere in the description on Amazon's website does it explain this.  Make sure you go to Apple's website to find out which pencil will work with your IPad BEFORE ordering one.

title: Self-Sabotaged After Warranty Expired
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2021
text: I dropped $1k my iPad pro and apple pencil for digital art, because everyone said it‚Äôs the best combo for digital art. With the insane cost, I expected quality and durability. While it worked, it was great, and I made some phenomenal art. But 14 months after I bought the pencil (2 months after the warranty expired), it stopped working. It won‚Äôt show up in bluetooth devices, despite showing an ‚ÄúApple Pencil‚Äù message when I magnetically connect it to my iPad. It knows the pencil is there, but will not connect. Because the pencil is a simple, real pencil design, there are no lights, buttons, or screens to see what the issue is, and whether or not there‚Äôs a way to fix the pencil. After troubleshooting for 5+ hours, then troubleshooting with apple tech support for 1.5 hours, it still doesn‚Äôt work, and an out-of-warranty replacement is $110, plus $7 to ship back your old pencil. You save ten bucks, but the kicker is that a replacement only has a 90 day warranty, compared to a new pencil‚Äôs 12 month warranty. This feels like a pre-planned money grab by Apple. I will now be looking into an affordable, non-apple stylus for my digital art.

title: Stopped working after 18 months and Apple could not care less!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on July 14, 2021
text: Purchased new in December 2019. Stopped working in July 2021. In that time I used it to take notes at meetings, and my teenager used it to draw. Under 10 hours total usage.After an hour on the phone with Apple, they determined the pen was defective and offered to look at it - not fix it, look at it - for a $109 service fee.I told them that I have been an Apple customer for 15+ years, and that since the pencil was obviously defective, I hoped that they would fix it or replace it fort me. They didn't actually laugh, at least until the call ended, but they refused to do anything. "Constantine" said that the people who denied my request "do not take phone calls" and that I was welcome to give feedback on the website, but could not promise any response.I hope Apple treats you better than this if you buy a defective product, but don't count on it.

title: Awful company, little to no care about marketing their products.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 18, 2020
text: Well, I'm new to Apple products so I didn't realize the labrynthian product release plan they have across multiple items. I got the Apple Pencil 2 thinking that it would be compatible with the latest ipad. It is, if you bought the latest ipad PRO. If you have a regular ipad, no matter when it was released, sorry, you just bought a useless piece of plastic.All I've ever heard was that Apple is so good with support, compatibility, and ease of use. I guess I should've figured out that was a complete lie when I was simply trying to figure out which was the latest ipad! The legion of releases, generations, and years associated with each iteration is astounding, and now, this. If it doesn't have broad support across releases from the same year, why would you call it Pencil 2, instead of Pencil PRO, which is a far more fitting way of presenting it?!I'm convinced that Apple intentionally baffles people with the way it labels and presents its product labels, strictly to sell more of their stuff. They can cram the Pencil PRO. I share some of the blame, obviously, but this is ridiculous, and deceptive, at BEST.
